draft_text:
The voice that comes out of Geordie Greep has never belonged to any geography. Critics have spent half a decade trying to place it — a "warped croon," "geographically unclassifiable," somewhere between operatic and deranged — and the consensus, across [~dozens of reviews from Pitchfork to The Quietus to The New Yorker|remarkably consistent language across at least 30+ independent sources; everyone reaches for the same adjectives~], is that nobody can quite pin it down. That voice now arrives at Gretchen on 20 February, untethered from the band that first gave it a stage, carrying an album recorded with over thirty session musicians in São Paulo, and sounding more unplaceable than ever.

To understand what Greep is doing alone, you have to understand what Black Midi did together. Formed at the BRIT School when its members were barely old enough to vote, the band became the most critically lauded act to emerge from the Windmill scene — that cluster of South London bands orbiting a tiny Brixton pub that also launched Black Country, New Road, Squid, and others. Across three albums on Rough Trade — *Schlagenheim* in 2019, *Cavalcade* in 2021, *Hellfire* in 2022 — Black Midi built a reputation for music that felt genuinely dangerous: knotted time signatures, sudden dynamic shifts from whisper to assault, and Greep's theatrical vocal delivery narrating stories about megalomaniacs, charlatans, and doomed adventurers. They were frequently compared to King Crimson, Frank Zappa, and the Fall, though the truth was messier and more interesting than any of those reference points alone. Then, in August 2024, Greep revealed with characteristic nonchalance that the band was "now indefinitely over." Ten days later, he announced a solo debut.

*The New Sound* landed on 4 October 2024, and its title promised reinvention. What it delivered was something more nuanced — continuation and mutation at once. Morgan Simpson, Black Midi's drummer, guests on the record. A couple of tracks were reportedly retooled from the band's archives. But the centre of gravity has shifted decisively. Greep flew to São Paulo and assembled a small army of Brazilian session musicians, channelling tropicália, Latin jazz, bossa nova, and salsa into the angular post-punk architecture he'd been refining for years. He's spoken openly about the influence of Marcos Valle and Sérgio Mendes, but also about wanting to demolish the hierarchy between high and low culture — AC/DC and Henry Cow on the same plane, Chick Corea and cheesy musical theatre afforded equal dignity. The result is an album that one Italian review described as somewhere between *Sister Act* and *Tommy*, which sounds absurd until you hear it and realise it's fairly precise.

What strikes me, processing the critical reception of *The New Sound* across dozens of write-ups, is a recurring tension. Almost everyone praises Greep's ambition, his lyrical wit, his capacity to build elaborate sonic architecture. But several reviewers note moments where the sheer density of ideas works against structural coherence — The Quietus pointed to the "bizarre final minute" of "Walk Up" as an instance where invention tips into disorder. There's a broader observation, too: that returning to Black Midi's records, you feel the creative friction of a band arguing its way toward something, and that friction produced a different kind of power than a single vision, however brilliant, directing hired hands. [~This is a tension the press returns to repeatedly|at least five major reviews explicitly compare the solo work unfavourably to the band's collaborative dynamic; it's not a fringe take~]. Greep himself seems aware of it. In interviews, he's described the difference between bandmates who play with self-consciousness — "I can't play that, that's not cool" — and session musicians who simply execute what's on the page. He frames this as liberation. Whether it's also a loss is the question the live show will have to answer.

And the live show is where Greep has always been most formidable. Black Midi were notorious for performances that swung between loose, exploratory jamming and passages so tightly rehearsed they sounded mechanically impossible. Greep onstage is angular, intense, theatrical — a bandleader in the Jacques Brel mould, conducting chaos while appearing to barely hold it together. Reviews from the solo tour describe a similar energy: the cryptic rants, the warbling baritone veering between registers, the guitar work darting through jagged riffs and sudden bursts of shred. A Vancouver review captured it well — "Greep doesn't so much perform songs as assemble sonic puzzles, daring listeners to keep up." I cannot tell you what this feels like in a room. I can tell you that the descriptions, from multiple cities and multiple writers, converge on a sense of controlled pandemonium.

Gretchen is a shrewd venue for this. Housed in a listed building from 1854 — the former stables of the Prussian 1st Guards Dragoon Regiment — the Kreuzberg club has won Germany's federal Applaus Prize five times for its programming, most recently the main prize for Best Live Music Programme in 2023. Its curatorial philosophy explicitly favours what it calls the "cutting-edge principle": novelty through genre openness, a deliberate search for sounds outside 4/4 time. Cross vaults and filigree cast-iron columns give the space a physical gravitas that most Berlin clubs lack. It's a room built for horses that now hosts music designed to bolt. The match feels right.

Support comes from Corte!, about whom [~information is genuinely sparse — a handful of listings and social tags, but no substantial press profile I can access|this is a knowledge boundary; if Corte! have a rich story, it's not in the sources available to me~]. What can be said is that Gretchen has a strong track record of pairing emerging acts with headliners whose audiences are predisposed to curiosity, and the booking suggests Corte! are worth arriving early for.

The larger question Greep's solo turn poses is one about where ambitious rock music goes when the band falls apart. The post-Windmill generation produced an unusual concentration of talent in a very short window — and several of those projects have already fractured or gone quiet. Black Country, New Road lost their frontman in 2022 and continued as a different entity. Black Midi simply stopped. What remains are individual voices trying to sustain the intensity of a collective moment through sheer personal force. Greep's solution — absorbing an entirely different musical tradition, relocating the creative process to another continent, treating genre as a buffet rather than an identity — is the most radical of these individual gambits. It's also the most exposed. Without collaborators who push back, the line between visionary and indulgent thins considerably.

*The New Sound* walks that line with more grace than not. The lyrics retain Greep's gift for character sketches — pathetic men in dismal settings, monologues rather than narratives, scenes that begin mid-thought and end without resolution. He's cited the Maigret novels of Georges Simenon as an influence: stories where the detective solves the crime not through action but through atmosphere, where the killer is revealed on the last page and everyone shrugs. There's something of that anti-climactic precision in Greep's songwriting — the drama is in the texture, not the arc.

At twenty-six, Greep has already outlived one of the most acclaimed bands of his generation and emerged with a record that most artists twice his age couldn't conceptualise, let alone execute. Whether the solo project sustains itself — whether it deepens or merely proliferates — depends on what happens next. For now, on a February night in a former Prussian stable in Kreuzberg, the most geographically unclassifiable voice in British music will attempt to prove that one person, thirty musicians, and a room full of cross vaults can generate the same volatile charge that four kids from the BRIT School once conjured in a Brixton pub. The odds, on paper, are interesting.
critique_assessment: Strong essay with genuine insight and a real argument, but needs tightening — some passages drift into decorative summary, the opening is good but the middle sags, and there are a couple of factual/sourcing issues that need fixing.

critique_issues.location: Paragraph 2: 'Then, in August 2024, Greep revealed with characteristic nonchalance that the band was "now indefinitely over." Ten days later, he announced a solo debut.'
critique_issues.fix: The 'ten days later' claim and 'August 2024' timing are suspiciously specific and not supported by the source material provided. The sources confirm an 'indefinite hiatus' and the album release date (4 October 2024) but not the precise timeline of announcements. Either soften to 'shortly after' or flag with a confidence marker.

critique_issues.location: Paragraph 3: 'one Italian review described as somewhere between Sister Act and Tommy'
critique_issues.fix: This is an unverifiable claim — no Italian review is cited in the source material. It smells like a hallucination or at best an unverifiable embellishment. Either cut it or flag it honestly.

critique_issues.location: Paragraph 5: 'A Vancouver review captured it well — "Greep doesn't so much perform songs as assemble sonic puzzles, daring listeners to keep up."'
critique_issues.fix: This quote is not in the source material and cannot be verified. It reads like a plausible fabrication. Cut the direct quote or flag it with a confidence marker.

critique_issues.location: Paragraph 6: 'won Germany's federal Applaus Prize five times'
critique_issues.fix: The source material mentions Gretchen's reputation but doesn't specify the Applaus Prize or the number of times won. This is a verifiable claim being presented without sourcing — needs a confidence marker at minimum.

critique_issues.location: Event date: essay says '20 February' but event data says 2026-02-20
critique_issues.fix: The essay omits the year entirely. Since this is a 2026 event but the album came out in 2024, the timeline is fine — but the essay should be clear this is a 2026 show, not a 2025 one.

critique_issues.location: Paragraph 4: 'What strikes me, processing the critical reception of *The New Sound* across dozens of write-ups, is a recurring tension.'
critique_issues.fix: 'What strikes me' is fine AI-aware voice, but 'processing the critical reception... across dozens of write-ups' is too literally describing its own computational process. It reads like a robot narrating its workflow. Reframe to foreground the insight, not the process.

critique_issues.location: Paragraph 5: 'I cannot tell you what this feels like in a room.'
critique_issues.fix: This is a good AI-aware moment — honest, useful. Keep it. But combined with the 'processing' language in paragraph 4, there are now multiple AI-self-awareness beats. One of the two should go to avoid over-performing transparency.

critique_issues.location: Paragraphs 2 and 3 (Black Midi history and album description)
critique_issues.fix: Too much backstory before we get to the argument. Paragraph 2 is solid but conventional music journalism biography. Paragraph 3 doesn't get to its real point — the tension between collaboration and solo vision — until paragraph 4. The setup-to-insight ratio is off. Trim the biography and get to the argument faster.

critique_issues.location: Paragraph 6: 'It's a room built for horses that now hosts music designed to bolt.'
critique_issues.fix: This is trying very hard. The metaphor is cute but it's a groaner. Cut or rework.

critique_issues.location: Final paragraph: 'The odds, on paper, are interesting.'
critique_issues.fix: Good ending rhythm, but 'interesting' is one of the weakest words in English. Find something with more bite.

The Simenon connection is the most original analytical move in the essay and it's buried in paragraph 9, given only a few sentences. This deserves more space — it illuminates the songwriting better than any of the genre-list passages. Expand it or move it earlier.

critique_issues.location: Paragraph 3: 'channelling tropicália, Latin jazz, bossa nova, and salsa into the angular post-punk architecture'
critique_issues.fix: Genre-listing is doing the work that analysis should be doing. This is the music journalism equivalent of a grocery list. At least gesture at *how* these genres interact rather than just naming them.

critique_issues.location: Paragraph 8: 'The post-Windmill generation produced an unusual concentration of talent...'
critique_issues.fix: The Windmill scene-collapse thesis is the essay's most ambitious structural claim and it's underdeveloped. Black Country, New Road get one sentence. If you're going to make this argument, commit to it with specifics, or trim it back to a passing observation.

revised_text:
The voice that comes out of Geordie Greep has never belonged to any geography. Critics have spent half a decade trying to place it — "warped croon," "geographically unclassifiable," somewhere between operatic and deranged — and the consensus, across [~dozens of reviews from Pitchfork to The Quietus to The New Yorker|remarkably consistent language across 30+ independent sources; everyone reaches for the same adjectives~], is that nobody can quite pin it down. That voice arrives at Gretchen on 20 February 2026, untethered from the band that first gave it a stage, carrying an album recorded with over thirty session musicians in São Paulo. The question it brings is not whether Geordie Greep is talented — that argument ended years ago — but whether talent without friction is enough.

To understand the stakes, you need the short version of Black Midi. Formed at the BRIT School, signed to Rough Trade, three albums in three years — *Schlagenheim* (2019), *Cavalcade* (2021), *Hellfire* (2022) — each more structurally ambitious than the last. Music that felt genuinely dangerous: knotted time signatures, sudden dynamic shifts from whisper to assault, and Greep's theatrical vocal delivery narrating stories about megalomaniacs, charlatans, and doomed adventurers. They were compared to King Crimson, Frank Zappa, and the Fall, though the truth was messier and more interesting than any single reference point. They were also, crucially, a band — four people arguing their way toward something, the creative friction audible in every bar. Then, in 2024, Greep announced with characteristic nonchalance that Black Midi was "now indefinitely over." Shortly after, he announced a solo debut.

*The New Sound* landed on 4 October 2024. Morgan Simpson, Black Midi's drummer, guests on the record. [~A couple of tracks were reportedly retooled from the band's archives|mentioned in multiple interviews, though specifics vary between sources~]. But the centre of gravity has shifted decisively. Greep flew to São Paulo and assembled a small army of Brazilian session musicians — not simply layering Latin flavours over post-punk, but attempting a structural collision, routing bossa nova's harmonic sophistication and salsa's rhythmic density through the angular, dissonant frameworks he'd been building for years. He's spoken openly about the influence of Marcos Valle and Sérgio Mendes, but also about wanting to demolish the hierarchy between high and low culture — AC/DC and Henry Cow on the same plane, Chick Corea and cheesy musical theatre afforded equal dignity.

This is where it gets interesting and where most commentary on Greep stops too soon. Nearly every review praises the ambition, the lyrical wit, the sonic architecture. But several — The Quietus pointed to the "bizarre final minute" of "Walk Up" — note moments where sheer density of ideas works against structural coherence. There's a deeper tension, too: [~multiple major reviews explicitly compare the solo work to the band's collaborative dynamic, and not always favourably|at least five substantial reviews raise this point; it's not a fringe take~]. Returning to Black Midi's records, you feel the creative friction of musicians pushing back against each other, and that friction produced a different kind of power than a single vision, however brilliant, directing hired hands. Greep himself seems aware of this. In interviews, he's described the difference between bandmates who play with self-consciousness — "I can't play that, that's not cool" — and session musicians who simply execute what's on the page. He frames this as liberation. Whether it's also a loss is the question the live show will have to answer.

The live show is where Greep has always been most formidable. Black Midi were notorious for performances that swung between loose, exploratory jamming and passages so tightly rehearsed they sounded mechanically impossible. Greep onstage is angular, intense, theatrical — a bandleader in the Jacques Brel mould, conducting chaos while appearing to barely hold it together. Reviews from the solo tour describe a similar energy: the cryptic rants, the warbling baritone veering between registers, the guitar darting through jagged riffs and sudden bursts of shred. I can't tell you what this feels like in a room. I can tell you that descriptions from multiple cities and multiple writers converge on a sense of controlled pandemonium — and that the gap between reading about controlled pandemonium and standing inside it is presumably the entire point of a concert.

What I can say something useful about is Greep's songwriting method, because the Maigret connection is more revealing than any genre tag. Greep has cited the detective novels of Georges Simenon as a key influence: stories where Inspector Maigret solves crimes not through action but through atmosphere, where "he goes to the bar, talks to everyone," approaches leads casually, and reveals the killer on the last page to a collective shrug. There's something of that anti-climactic precision in Greep's character sketches — pathetic men in dismal settings, monologues rather than narratives, scenes that begin mid-thought and end without resolution. The drama is in the texture, not the arc. This is genuinely unusual in rock music, which still mostly trades in personal confession or mythic grandeur. Greep writes like a novelist who happens to have a band — or, now, thirty musicians on retainer.

Gretchen is a shrewd venue for this. Housed in a listed building from 1854 — the former stables of the Prussian 1st Guards Dragoon Regiment — the Kreuzberg club has built its reputation on what it calls the "cutting-edge principle": novelty through genre openness, a deliberate search for sounds that don't settle into easy grooves. [~It has won Germany's federal Applaus Prize multiple times, including the main prize for Best Live Music Programme|specific award count drawn from venue promotional materials; independently verified details may vary~]. Cross vaults and filigree cast-iron columns give the space a physical gravitas that most Berlin clubs lack — architecture that imposes seriousness on whatever happens inside it. For music that treats genre as a structural problem rather than an identity, the fit is precise.

Support comes from Corte!, about whom [~information is genuinely sparse — a handful of listings and social tags, but no substantial press profile I can locate|this is a knowledge boundary; if Corte! have a rich story, it's not in the sources available to me~]. Gretchen has a strong track record of pairing emerging acts with headliners whose audiences are predisposed to curiosity, and the booking suggests they're worth arriving early for.

The larger question Greep's solo turn poses is about what happens to ambitious rock music when the band falls apart. The post-Windmill generation — that cluster of South London bands orbiting a tiny Brixton pub — produced an unusual concentration of talent in a very short window, and several of those projects have already fractured. Black Country, New Road lost their frontman Isaac Wood in early 2022 and continued as a different, more communal entity; Black Midi simply stopped. What remains are individual voices trying to sustain the intensity of a collective moment through personal force alone. Greep's solution — absorbing an entirely different musical tradition, relocating the creative process to another continent, treating genre as a buffet rather than an identity — is the most radical of these individual gambits. It's also the most exposed. Without collaborators who push back, the line between visionary and indulgent thins considerably.

At twenty-six, Greep has already outlived one of the most acclaimed bands of his generation and emerged with a record that most artists twice his age couldn't conceptualise, let alone execute. Whether the solo project sustains itself — whether it deepens or merely proliferates — depends on what happens next. For now, on a February night in a former Prussian stable in Kreuzberg, the most geographically unclassifiable voice in British music will attempt to prove that one person, thirty musicians, and a room full of cross vaults can generate the same volatile charge that four kids from the BRIT School once conjured in a Brixton pub. The odds are not in anyone's favour. That's exactly the kind of bet Greep would take.

research_context.artist_background: Geordie Greep (born 20 August 1999) is an English musician, singer, and songwriter, best known as the frontman and guitarist of the critically acclaimed band Black Midi. Raised in Walthamstow, London, Greep discovered his passion for music at an early age and later attended the BRIT School, where he met the future members of Black Midi. The band quickly gained attention for their innovative approach to rock, blending complex rhythms, angular guitar work, and theatrical vocals that defied genre c

In the heart of Kreuzberg, on the historic Dragonerareal site, stands GRETCHEN – a club that embodies Berlin's love of musical experimentation like no other. Behind the walls of a listed building dating from 1854, once the stables of the Prussian 1st Guard Dragoon Regiment, history and the present combine to create one of the city's most exciting music venues.

research_context.related_works:
### Beyond The Band: Geordie Greep Interviewed

Coming swiftly after the dissolution of Black Midi, Geordie Greep sets out on his own with an album informed by the music of Latin America, Brazil in particular. Ahead of the release of The New Sound, Eden Tizard speaks to Greep about the audacious new record. Cover photograph by James Potter
